abstract.p: David Shaughnessy letter on Anthony Lewis's statement that prosecuting a President, or anyone, for lying about sex is 'grotesque notion'; contends there is no 'sex' exception to perjury and obstruction of justice laws

block.p: Anthony Lewis writes that ''prosecuting a President, or anyone, for lying about sex is a grotesque notion'' (column, Feb. 23). Yet there is no ''sex'' exception to perjury and obstruction-of-justice laws.

Anthony Lewis writes that ''prosecuting a President, or anyone, for lying about sex is a grotesque notion'' (column, Feb. 23). Yet there is no ''sex'' exception to perjury and obstruction-of-justice laws.
Witnesses are not permitted to base their honesty on their assessment of the legitimacy of the inquiry's subject matter. Courts decide when questions are improper.

Also, since one of the recognized goals of criminal law is deterrence, high-profile offenders are often prosecuted where others might not be. Yes, it is true that people are seldom prosecuted for perjury and obstruction of justice in civil cases. But if a President were not punished for that misconduct, those corrosive practices would be reinforced and encouraged.
